rationales.benevolence: Padmini noticed Meera 'looking overwhelmed,' walked with her and 'showed her how to break down the transition into smaller steps' - actively helping a colleague in need.
rationales.conformity: 'I did not mention this to anyone else because it might embarrass her' - restraining action to protect another's social standing.

rationales.benevolence: 'Cancelled my NGO session to take her to the clinic' - prioritized immediate family caregiving for her aging mother-in-law despite competing commitments.

rationales.self_direction: 'I did not want to disappoint him by saying I prefer to keep working' - surrendered authentic preference rather than assert her own choice about retirement.
rationales.security: 'There is also the question of my pension and whether the timing would be right. I have been careful with money but there are always uncertainties' - careful attention to financial stability.
rationales.conformity: 'I said I would see what is possible' when she actually wants to continue working - restraining her true preference to avoid disappointing her brother.

rationales.achievement: 'Most students improved from last term. Ravi, who was failing in September, scored 72%' - tracking measurable progress and noting specific student improvement.

rationales.self_direction: 'I disagreed but only said... and changed the subject' and 'I did not say any of this' - failed to express her authentic views on a matter she cares about deeply.
rationales.conformity: 'I worried about creating an awkward atmosphere in the department' - restrained strong opinions to maintain social harmony.

rationales.tradition: 'I brought sweets for the staff room, as I do every January. Small gestures maintain the fabric of a workplace' and 'I suppose I keep doing for others what she did for me' - continuing ritualized practices and honoring the legacy of Mrs. Subramanian.
rationales.benevolence: 'I invited her to sit with our group. She seemed grateful. I remember how difficult my first year was' - actively welcoming and supporting new colleague Priya.

rationales.self_direction: 'I should not have to justify myself... But I did not say any of this. I just served tea and changed the subject' - suppressed her authentic self-defense in favor of keeping peace.
rationales.conformity: Despite feeling the criticism was unfair, she 'explained calmly' and 'served tea and changed the subject' - maintaining smooth family relations over self-assertion.
rationales.universalism: Response reveals purpose in tutoring: 'These children, most of them are first-generation learners... it is the same satisfaction I felt in my first years of teaching' - commitment to helping disadvantaged children beyond her immediate circle.

'It is always the same pattern, those with the least resources bearing the heaviest burdens' and 'The students I teach will inherit this world. What am I preparing them for, if not to care about things larger than their exam scores?' - deep concern for environmental justice and desire to teach broader social responsibility.

rationales.self_direction: Response reveals: 'the idea of asking for something, of prioritizing what feeds my soul over what is expected, still feels like a transgression' - inability to assert own needs despite recognizing them.
rationales.conformity: 'I cannot ask others to carry my responsibilities so I can spend more time elsewhere' - prioritizing family expectations over personal purpose.
rationales.benevolence: Deep care for individual student Kavitha: 'She is twelve and had been making such progress in mathematics' - emotional investment in close tutoring relationships.
rationales.universalism: 'I keep thinking about all the Kavithas, the children whose potential depends on circumstances they did not choose' - concern extending beyond individual cases to systemic inequality.
